# [Remove last argument from argument list of shell script (bash)](/questions/20398499/remove-last-argument-from-argument-list-of-shell-script-bash){.question-hyperlink} {#remove-last-argument-from-argument-list-of-shell-script-bash .fs-headline1 .ow-break-word .mb8 .flex--item .fl1 itemprop="name"}

[Ask Question](/questions/ask){.ws-nowrap .s-btn .s-btn__filled}

9 years, 10 months ago

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyBhcmlhLWhpZGRlbj0idHJ1ZSIgY2xhc3M9InN2Zy1pY29uIGljb25BcnJvd1VwIiB3aWR0aD0iMTgiIGhlaWdodD0iMTgiIHZpZXdib3g9IjAgMCAxOCAxOCI+PHBhdGggZD0iTTEgMTJoMTZMOSA0bC04IDhaIj48L3BhdGg+PC9zdmc+){.svg-icon .iconArrowUp}

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyBhcmlhLWhpZGRlbj0idHJ1ZSIgY2xhc3M9ImZjLXRoZW1lLXByaW1hcnktNDAwIGpzLXNhdmVzLWJ0bi1zZWxlY3RlZCBkLW5vbmUgc3ZnLWljb24gaWNvbkJvb2ttYXJrIiB3aWR0aD0iMTgiIGhlaWdodD0iMTgiIHZpZXdib3g9IjAgMCAxOCAxOCI+PHBhdGggZD0iTTMgMTdWM2MwLTEuMS45LTIgMi0yaDhhMiAyIDAgMCAxIDIgMnYxNGwtNi00LTYgNFoiPjwvcGF0aD48L3N2Zz4=){.fc-theme-primary-400 .js-saves-btn-selected .d-none .svg-icon .iconBookmark}
![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.js-saves-btn-unselected .svg-icon .iconBookmarkAlt}

[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.mln2 .mr0 .svg-icon .iconHistory}](/posts/20398499/timeline "Show activity on this post."){.js-post-issue .flex--item .s-btn .s-btn__unset .c-pointer .py6 .mx-auto shortcut="T" ks-title="timeline" controller="s-tooltip" s-tooltip-placement="right" aria-label="Timeline"}

This question concerns a bash script that is run in automator osx. I am using automator actions to get and filter a bunch of file references from the finder. Then I append to that list the name of the parent folder, also via an automator action. Automator then feeds these arguments to an action called \"run shell script\". I am not sure exactly how automator invokes the script but the argument list looks like this when echoed with: `echo "$@"`

> /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/01/01000 43-001.wav /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/02/02000 43-002.wav /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/03/03000 43-003.wav /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50

In this case path to 3 files and a folder.

In the shell script I launch an application called ripcheckc\* with the args passed from automator minus the last argument(the folder) in the list.

I use this to remove the last argument:

    _args=( "$@" )
    unset _args[${#_args[@]}-1]

And this is `echo $_args`:

> /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/01/01000 43-001.wav /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/02/02000 43-002.wav /Volumes/G-Raid/Online/WAV_TEST/Testbok 50/03/03000 43-003.wav

Same as before but without the folder.

Now, if I run ripcheckc with `"$@"` as argument it works (but fails later on because of that last path in the argument list) If I use `${_args[@]}` the application will just abort silently. When I echo `$@` and `_args` the output looks identical except for the last argument.

My question is - what is the difference between \$@ and \$\_args that make the first valid input and the second not?

\*The application is [ripcheckc](http://sourceforge.net/projects/ripcheck/files/?source=navbar){rel="noreferrer"}

I hope my question makes sense.

EDIT: Solved.

-   [I solved it by using double quotes. Like this: ripcheckc \"\${\_args\[@\]}\".]{#comment-30467604}

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyBhcmlhLWhpZGRlbj0idHJ1ZSIgY2xhc3M9InN2Zy1pY29uIGljb25DaGVja21hcmtMZyIgd2lkdGg9IjM2IiBoZWlnaHQ9IjM2IiB2aWV3Ym94PSIwIDAgMzYgMzYiPjxwYXRoIGQ9Im02IDE0IDggOEwzMCA2djhMMTQgMzBsLTgtOHYtOFoiPjwvcGF0aD48L3N2Zz4=){.svg-icon .iconCheckmarkLg}

[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.mln2 .mr0 .svg-icon .iconHistory}](/posts/26163980/timeline "Show activity on this post."){.js-post-issue .flex--item .s-btn .s-btn__unset .c-pointer .py6 .mx-auto shortcut="T" ks-title="timeline" controller="s-tooltip" s-tooltip-placement="right" aria-label="Timeline"}

I have used this `bash` one-liner before

    set -- "${@:1:$(($#-1))}"

It sets the argument list to the current argument list, less the last argument.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

How it works:

-   `$#` is the number of arguments
-   `$((...))` is an arithmetic expression, so `$(($#-1))` is one less than the number of arguments.
-   `${variable:position:count}` is a [substring expression](http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/string-manipulation.html){rel="noreferrer"}: it extracts `count` characters from `variable` starting at position. In the [special case](http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/string-manipulation.html){rel="noreferrer"} where `variable` is `@`, which means the argument list, it extracts `count` **arguments** from the list beginning at `position`. Here, `position` is `1` for the first argument and `count` is one less than the number of arguments worked out previously.
-   `set -- arg1...argn` [sets the argument list](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/The-Set-Builtin.html){rel="noreferrer"} to the given arguments

So the end result is that the argument list is replaced with a new list, where the new list is the original list except for the last argument.

[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.mln2 .mr0 .svg-icon .iconHistory}](/posts/20398578/timeline "Show activity on this post."){.js-post-issue .flex--item .s-btn .s-btn__unset .c-pointer .py6 .mx-auto shortcut="T" ks-title="timeline" controller="s-tooltip" s-tooltip-placement="right" aria-label="Timeline"}

Assuming that you already have an `array`, you can say:

    unset "array[${#array[@]}-1]"

------------------------------------------------------------------------

For example, if your script contains:

    array=( "$@" )
    unset "array[${#array[@]}-1]"    # Removes last element -- also see: help unset
    for i in "${array[@]}"; do
      echo "$i"
    done

invoking it with: `bash scriptname foo bar baz` produces:

    foo
    bar

[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.mln2 .mr0 .svg-icon .iconHistory}](/posts/20401782/timeline "Show activity on this post."){.js-post-issue .flex--item .s-btn .s-btn__unset .c-pointer .py6 .mx-auto shortcut="T" ks-title="timeline" controller="s-tooltip" s-tooltip-placement="right" aria-label="Timeline"}

You can also get all but the last argument with

    "${@:0:$#}"

which, honestly, is a little sketchy, since it seems to be (ab)using the fact that arguments are numbered starting with 1, not 0.

Update: This only works due to a bug (fixed in 4.1.2 at the latest) in handling `$@`. It works in version 3.2.

-   [11]{#comment-46333551}
    Code `"${@:1:${#}-1}"` is exactly what makes full list of arguments like in \"\$@\" without the last one.
    -- [uvsmtid](/users/441652/uvsmtid "4,207 reputation"){.comment-user}
    Mar 14, 2015 at 9:49
-   [Right. The sketchy part is using 0 as the first argument to avoid having to subtract 1 from the second.]{#comment-46335085}
    -- [chepner](/users/1126841/chepner "500,880 reputation"){.comment-user}
    Mar 14, 2015 at 11:33
-   [Actually, index 0 includes non-argument - path to the script being executed (a value automatically provided by shell). You are not avoiding subtraction of 1 - the last argument is still included and you must subtract 1. Using 0 is simply adding one more (likely not required) value to the list.]{#comment-46335150}
    -- [uvsmtid](/users/441652/uvsmtid "4,207 reputation"){.comment-user}
    Mar 14, 2015 at 11:38
    ![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.va-text-bottom .o50 .svg-icon .iconPencilSm}
-   [1]{#comment-46335235}
    It would appear this worked in `bash` 3.2 due to a bug that was subsequently fixed.
    -- [chepner](/users/1126841/chepner "500,880 reputation"){.comment-user}
    Mar 14, 2015 at 11:43

    set -- "${@:1:$#-1}"

sets the parameter list to first up to penultimate, removing the last one
